access.description: The registered URL redirects (301) from reportingmd.com to www.reportingmd.com, then returns 200. The page is hosted on Wix (Thunderbolt framework) and renders content via JavaScript. However, the PDF download link is discoverable in the raw HTML source via grep. The page itself is very simple: a title ('ReportingMD EHI Export Specifications Version 1.0'), a single link labeled 'EHI Export' pointing to the PDF, and a footer with site navigation. No accordion sections, no multi-step navigation, no anti-bot protection.

products.name: Total Outcomes Management (TOM)

product_context.description: Total Outcomes Management (TOM) is a population health analytics and quality reporting platform — NOT an EHR. It functions as a clinical data warehouse that ingests data from 50+ EMRs via configurable connectors, plus claims data, Social Determinants of Health (SDoH) data, and ADT feeds. TOM normalizes this data at the patient level for quality measure calculation and value-based care analytics. ReportingMD is a CMS-designated Qualified Registry for MIPS reporting. The product serves ACOs (e.g., Tufts Medicine ACO, Vermont All-Payer ACO), clinically integrated networks, medical groups, and specialty practices. TOM supports programs including ACO REACH, MIPS, MSSP, HCC Risk Adjustment, HEDIS/STARS Analytics, and APCM. The certified criteria confirm TOM is not a clinical system: it lacks all (a)(1)-(a)(14) clinical criteria, has no patient portal (e)(1), no public health reporting (f)(1)-(f)(7), and no FHIR API (g)(7)-(g)(10). The certification covers only EHI export (b)(10), CQM calculation (c)(2)-(c)(3), security (d) criteria, and QMS (g)(4)-(g)(5)).

export_approach.description: The export is a simple Microsoft Excel (.xlsx) spreadsheet containing only patient demographic data. For a single patient, data appears in one row; for a population export, data appears in multiple rows. This is effectively a patient matching roster dump — the demographic identifiers TOM stores for linking patients across disparate data sources. It is not a database dump, not FHIR, and not C-CDA. The export contains zero clinical content, zero quality measure results, zero claims data, and zero analytics output. The data element list (24 columns, only 11 actually populated) appears modeled on HIPAA's 18 identifier categories rather than on TOM's actual data model.

documentation_quality.description: The entire EHI export specification is a single-page PDF. It contains a three-bullet summary, a table of 24 data elements with column locations and types, and a footnote. There is no schema documentation for TOM's underlying data warehouse, no description of the analytics data model, no explanation of what data categories exist in the system but are excluded from the export, and no versioning or update history beyond 'Version 1.0'. For a data warehouse that ingests and processes data from 50+ EMRs, the documentation is remarkably sparse.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The EHI export covers only patient demographics — 11 fields (Patient ID, Name, DOB, Gender, Street Address, City, ZIP Code, Date of Death, Phone Number, Email Address, SSN). This is a patient matching roster, not a comprehensive EHI export. TOM stores substantial data beyond demographics: it ingests and normalizes clinical data from 50+ EMRs, processes adjudicated claims data, stores SDoH data, computes 40+ clinical quality measures, calculates HCC risk scores, and generates HEDIS/STARS analytics. None of this stored data appears in the export. While TOM is not an EHR and some categories (messaging, scheduling, document management) are genuinely not applicable, the system's core function — aggregating and analyzing health data — produces and stores health information that is absent from the export. The quality measure results, risk scores, and aggregated clinical data warehouse contents are all arguably EHI under the b(10) requirement.

clinical.evidence: Zero clinical data elements in the export specification. No diagnoses, medications, labs, vitals, procedures, allergies, or any clinical content. The specification lists only demographic identifiers. However, TOM's clinical data warehouse ingests and stores clinical data from 50+ EMRs — this data is not exported.

secure_messages.evidence: Not applicable. TOM does not have messaging functionality. No patient portal criterion (e)(1) is certified.

billing_financial.evidence: Not present in export. TOM ingests adjudicated claims data for analytics and HCC risk adjustment, but this claims data is not included in the export.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Not present. The specification lists 'Health Plan Beneficiary Numbers' as a data element but marks it with an asterisk as 'not collected.' TOM processes claims/payer data for analytics but does not export it.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Not applicable. TOM does not have scheduling functionality.

documents_images.evidence: Not present. The specification lists 'Images' as a data element but marks it as 'not collected.'

audit_trails.evidence: No audit trail data in the export specification.

issues: Extremely minimal export scope: the entire EHI export is 11 demographic fields in a single Excel spreadsheet, despite TOM being a data warehouse that stores clinical, claims, SDoH, and analytics data from 50+ source systems.

Missing quality measure results: TOM calculates 40+ CQMs, HCC risk scores, and HEDIS measures. These computed results are stored health information arguably covered by b(10), yet they are entirely absent from the export.
Missing ingested clinical data: TOM normalizes clinical data from 50+ EMRs into its data warehouse. This aggregated clinical data is stored by the product but not exported.
Missing claims data: TOM ingests and stores adjudicated claims data for analytics, but does not include it in the export.

Data element list appears modeled on HIPAA's 18 identifiers rather than on what TOM actually stores — many columns are HIPAA identifiers that TOM doesn't collect (Vehicle Identifiers, Device Identifiers, Biometric Identifiers), while the system's actual stored data (quality measures, risk scores, clinical aggregations, claims) is entirely unrepresented.
Single-page documentation for a product that serves as a multi-source clinical data warehouse — no description of the data model, no explanation of excluded data categories, no schema documentation.
products.summary: TOM is a population health analytics platform (not an EHR) that aggregates clinical and claims data from 50+ EMRs for quality measure calculation and value-based care analytics. Despite storing substantial health data, its EHI export contains only 11 patient demographic fields in a single Excel spreadsheet. The export specification is a single-page PDF that provides no insight into the system's underlying data warehouse or the clinical/claims/analytics data it processes and stores.

downloaded_files.description: ReportingMD EHI Export Specifications Version 1.0 — single-page PDF listing 24 data elements (11 actually collected) covering patient demographics only. Export format is Microsoft Excel (.xlsx).

summary: ReportingMD's Total Outcomes Management (TOM) is a population health analytics and quality reporting platform — not an EHR. It aggregates clinical and claims data from 50+ EMRs for CQM calculation, HCC risk adjustment, and value-based care analytics. Despite storing substantial health data, its EHI export is remarkably minimal: a single Excel spreadsheet containing only 11 patient demographic fields (ID, name, DOB, gender, address, city, ZIP, date of death, phone, email, SSN). The single-page export specification is modeled on HIPAA identifiers rather than on the system's actual data contents, leaving the clinical data warehouse, quality measure results, risk scores, and claims data entirely unrepresented in the export.
notes: TOM's certification profile is unusual — it holds only (b)(10) EHI export, (c)(2)-(c)(3) CQM, (d) security, and (g)(4)-(g)(5) QMS criteria, with no clinical (a), patient access (e), public health (f), or API (g)(7)-(g)(10) criteria. This narrow certification footprint reflects TOM's role as a secondary analytics system rather than a primary clinical system. The key compliance question is whether TOM's aggregated/derived data (quality measure scores, risk calculations, normalized clinical warehouse contents) constitutes 'EHI that can be stored at the time of certification by the product' — if so, the export is substantially incomplete.
